ABSTRACT During oil production, changes in composition, temperature, and pressure conditions occur, which can cause the precipitation of different solids, such as hydrates, asphaltenes, and waxes. The study of oils with high CO 2 content is extremely relevant since several reservoirs in this condition have been found in countries all over the world, including Brazil, with the discovery, exploration, and production of pre -salt wells. Besides, to optimize the reservoir production, a better thermodynamic description of the phase behavior of these fluids is needed. In order to understand the influence of light components, such as CO 2, mixtures of n -paraffins, in different conditions of temperature and pressure. In this work, experimental data of mixtures of n -alkanes with high CO 2 content at high pressure were obtained. The systems studied are mixtures formed by CO 2 and a series of n -alkanes (n -C10H22 / n-C20H42, n-C10H22 / n-C24H50, n-C10H22 / n-C20H42 / n-C24H50) with varying weight fraction of CO 2 of 55% 65% and 75% in the temperature range of 273 K to 363 K and pressures up to 55 MPa, using a high -pressure phase equilibrium cell. The UNIQUAC -modified model, together with the parameter determination strategy, proved to be adequate to describe the propert ies of the solid phase, determinations within the experimental uncertainty. The vapor -liquid transitions were modeled using the Peng -Robinson equation of state (PR -EOS). The results show an average error of 0.5% when calculating the crystal appearance temp erature and 4.5% when calculating the saturation pressure of the studied systems.
